sentence-detokenized: The EU rejects the German call for a boycott of British lamb.
Peter Blackburn
BRUSSELS 1996-08-22

The European Commission said on Thursday it disagreed with German advice that consumers should avoid British lamb until scientists have established whether mad cow disease can be transmitted to sheep.

Werner Zwingmann, Germany's representative on the European Union's animal health committee, said on Wednesday that consumers should buy sheep meat from countries other than Britain until scientific advice is clearer.
"We do not support any such recommendation because we see no basis for it," said Nikolaus van der Pas, the Commission's chief spokesman, at a press conference.
He said that further scientific studies are needed and if it turns out that action is needed, the European Union should take it.

He said that Agriculture Commissioner Franz Fischler's proposal last month to ban sheep brains, spleens and spinal cords from the human and animal food chain was a very concrete and precautionary step to protect human health.
Fischler has proposed EU-wide measures following reports from Britain and France that sheep in laboratory conditions could be suffering from bovine spongiform encephalopathy (BSE) - mad cow disease.

However, Fischler agreed to review his proposal after the EU's Standing Veterinary Committee, national veterinary officials questioned whether such a measure was justified as it posed little risk to human health.
Earlier, Spanish Agriculture Minister Loyola de Palacio accused Fischler at a meeting of EU agriculture ministers of causing unwarranted alarm by "dangerous generalisations".
Only France and the UK supported Fischler's proposal.
The EU's Scientific Veterinary and Multidisciplinary Committees will re-examine the issue early next month and make recommendations to senior veterinary officials.
Sheep have long been known to be affected by a BSE-like brainworm disease, scrapie, which is believed to have been passed to cattle through feed containing animal waste.

British farmers on Thursday denied any risk to human health from the sheep they keep, but expressed concern that the German government's advice to consumers to avoid British lamb could influence consumers across Europe.
"We have to be very careful about how other countries will follow Germany's example," John Lloyd Jones, president of the National Farmers' Union (NFU) in Wales, told BBC radio.

Bonn has spearheaded efforts to protect public health after consumer confidence was shaken in March after a British report suggested that people could contract a disease similar to mad cow disease by eating contaminated beef.
Germany imported 47 600 sheep from Britain last year, almost half of the total.
It imported 4,275 tonnes of British mutton, around 10 percent of total imports.
A rare Hendrix painting sold for nearly $17 000.
A rare, handwritten early sketch of a song by American guitar legend Jimi Hendrix sold for almost $17,000 on Thursday at an auction of some of the late musician's favourite artefacts.
A restaurant in Florida paid £10 925 ($16 935) for a sketch of "Ain't no telling" that Hendrix wrote on letterhead in a London hotel in late 1966.
At the end of a concert in Nottingham, England, in January 1967, he threw a piece of paper into the audience, from where a fan retrieved it.
The buyers also snapped up 16 other items, which were auctioned by Hendrix's former girlfriend Kathy Etchingham, who lived with him between 1966 and 1969.
Among them was a black lacquer and pearl inlaid box that Hendrix used to store drugs, which was bought by an anonymous Australian buyer for £5,060 ($7,845).
The guitarist died of a drug overdose in 1970, aged 27.
China says Taiwan is spoiling the atmosphere for negotiations.
BEIJING 1996-08-22
China on Thursday accused Taipei of spoiling the mood for a resumption of talks across the Taiwan Strait with Taiwan Vice President Lien Chan's visit to Ukraine this week, which angered Beijing.

Foreign Ministry spokesman Shen Guofang told Reuters just hours after Chinese state media said the time had come for political talks with Taiwan: "The atmosphere for the start of talks has been disrupted by the Taiwanese authorities".
State media quoted Tang Shubei, China's chief negotiator with Taipei, as telling a group of visiting Taiwanese on Wednesday that it was time for the rivals to hold political talks.
"It is time for the two sides to engage in political talks...
to put an end to the state of hostilities," Tang was quoted as saying by the overseas edition of People's Daily on Thursday.

Foreign Ministry Shen told Reuters television in an interview that he had read reports of Tang's remarks, but gave no details of why the negotiator had deemed the time right for talks with Taiwan, which Beijing regards as a renegade province.
China, which has long opposed any attempt by Taipei to gain greater international recognition, was angered by Taiwanese Vice President Lien's visit to Ukraine this week.
China says it is time for talks in Taiwan.
BEIJING 1996-08-22
China said it was time for political talks with Taiwan and that the rival island should take practical steps to achieve this.

Consultations are to be held to determine the date and format of the talks, the official Xinhua news agency quoted Tang Shubei, executive vice-president of the Association for Cross-Strait Relations in Taiwan, as saying late on Wednesday.
July car registrations in Germany increased by 14.2 percent year-on-year.
FRANKFURT 1996-08-22
First registrations of German cars rose 14.2 percent in July this year compared with a year earlier, the Federal Motor Vehicle Office said on Thursday.
According to the agency, 356,725 new passenger cars - 304,850 cars and 15,613 trucks - were registered in July 1996.
The figures represent a 13.6 percent increase for passenger cars and a 2.2 percent decrease for trucks compared to July 1995.
Registrations of motorcycles increased by 32.7 percent in this period.
The increase was partly due to Germans buying more German cars abroad, while manufacturers said domestic demand was weak, the federal agency said.
Almost all German carmakers recorded an increase in registration numbers during this period.
Volkswagen AG won 77,719 registrations, which is just over a quarter of all registrations.
Opel AG, together with General Motors, came in second place with 49 269 registrations, representing 16.4 percent of the total.
Ford was third with 35 563 registrations, an 11.7 percent increase.
In July 1996, only Seat and Porsche registered fewer cars than in July last year.
Seat recorded 3,420 registrations, compared to 5,522 in July a year earlier.
Porsche registrations fell from 643 to 554.
GREEK SOCIALISTS GIVE THE GREEN LIGHT TO THE PRIME MINISTER TO STAND FOR ELECTION.
The Executive Committee of the Greek Socialist Party has given the go-ahead to Prime Minister Kostas Simitis to call early elections, Secretary General Kostas Skandalidis told reporters.
Prime Minister Costas Simitis will make an official announcement after the cabinet meeting on Thursday, Skandalidis said.
-- Dimitris Kontogiannis, Athens News Agency +301 3311812-4

Port conditions from Lloyds Shipping Intelligence Service --
LATAKIA, 10 August - The waiting time in Lattakia and Tartous is currently 24 hours.
Israel downplays fears of war with Syria.
Colleen Siegel
JERUSALEM 1996-08-22
Israel's outgoing Syrian peace negotiator said on Thursday that the current tensions between the two countries were a storm in a teacup.
Itamar Rabinovich, who as Israel's ambassador in Washington has been engaged in fruitless negotiations with Syria, told Israel Radio that Damascus seems to want to negotiate rather than fight.
"It seems to me that the {(1)[MISC] Syrian priority} remains the negotiations.
The Syrians are confused, they're definitely tense, but the general assessment here in Washington is that this is essentially a storm in a teacup," he said.
Rabinovic is nearing the end of his term as Ambassador.
He is replaced by Eliahu Ben-Elissar, former Israeli ambassador to Egypt and a right-wing Likud politician.
Israel sent a message to Syria via Washington on Wednesday, saying it is committed to peace and wants to start negotiations without preconditions.
But he also criticised Damascus for creating a dangerous atmosphere.
Syria on Wednesday accused Israel of launching a hysterical campaign against it after Israeli television reported that Damascus had recently carried out a missile test.
He said that his arms purchases were for defence purposes.

"The message that we sent to Syrian President (Hafez al-) Assad is that Israel is ready to start peace talks at any time, without preconditions," Israeli Foreign Minister David Levy said in an interview with Israel Radio.
Tensions have been escalating since Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu took office in June and vowed to keep the Golan Heights, which Israel seized from Syria in the 1967 Middle East war.
Israeli-Syrian peace talks have been deadlocked on the Golan Heights since 1991, despite the previous government's willingness to make concessions on the Golan Heights.
Peace talks between the two sides were last held in February.
"The voices coming from Damascus are bad, not good.
The media...
are full of expressions and statements that should be of concern...
this artificial atmosphere is very dangerous because those who spread it can be its prisoners," Levy said.
"We expect Syria, if it turns towards peace, to respond to Israel's message to start peace talks, because that is our goal," he said. "
We don't want war, God forbid.
No one profits from wars. "
According to Israel's Channel Two television, Damascus has sent a "reassuring signal" to Israel.
The source of the report was not provided.
Spokesmen for Netanyahu and Levy said they could not confirm.
The television also reported that Netanyahu had sent messages to reassure Syria via Cairo, the United States and Moscow.
Polish diplomat denies that nurses are stranded in Libya.
TUNISIA 1996-08-22

A Polish diplomat on Thursday refuted a report in a Polish tabloid this week that Libya had denied exit visas to 100 Polish nurses who wanted to return home after working in the North African country.
"This is not true.

To date, we are not aware of any of the nurses being trapped or held in Libya against their will, and we have not received any complaints," Tadeusz Awdankiewicz, a spokesman for the Polish embassy in Tripoli, told Reuters by telephone.

The Polish labour ministry said this week it would send a team to Libya to carry out the investigation, but Awdankiewicz said the inquiry was prompted by complaints from some nurses about their working conditions, including non-payment of their salaries.
He said that there are an estimated 800 Polish nurses working in Libya.
Two Iranian opposition leaders meet in Baghdad.
Hassan Hafidh
BAGHDAD 1996-08-22
An Iraq-based Iranian exile group vowed on Thursday to extend its support to Iranian Kurdish rebels after Iranian troops attacked them deep inside Iraq last month.

According to a statement, Mujahed Khalq leader Massoud Rajavi met with Iranian Kurdistan Democratic Party (KDPI) Secretary General Hassan Rastegar in Baghdad on Wednesday and expressed his support for the Iranian Kurdish rebels.
"Rajavi stressed that Iranian resistance fighters will continue to stand by their Kurdish compatriots and the Iranian Kurdistan resistance movement," the statement said.
A spokesman for the group said the meeting "marks a new level of cooperation between the Mujahedin Khalq and the Kurdish opposition in Iran".
In July, Iran heavily bombed targets in northern Iraq against KDPI guerrillas stationed in Iraqi Kurdish areas outside the control of the Baghdad government.
The Iraqi Kurdish areas bordering Iran are under the control of guerrillas of the Patriotic Union of Kurdistan in Iraq (PUK) group.
The PUK and the Kurdistan Democratic Party of Iraq (KDP), the two main Iraqi Kurdish factions, have controlled northern Iraq since Iraqi forces were pushed out of Kuwait in the 1991 Gulf War.
Clashes broke out between the two sides over the weekend, the heaviest fighting since last year's US-sponsored ceasefire.
According to Mujahideen Khalq, Iranian troops have also shelled KDP positions in the Qasri region of Suleymaniyah province near the Iranian border over the past two days.
He said that about 100 Iraqi Kurds were killed or wounded in the attack.
Iran and Turkey both launch air and ground strikes on targets in northern Iraq against their own Kurdish rebels.
The US-led air force is protecting Iraqi Kurds in southern Turkey from possible attacks by Baghdad troops.
The Saudi riyal is stable in quiet summer trading.
The Saudi riyal's spot rate against the dollar and interbank deposit rates in the kingdom have been mostly stable in quiet summer trading this week, according to dealers in the kingdom.
"There has been no change in the Saudi riyal exchange rate.
The market was very quiet because of the summer holidays," said one trader.
The spot riyal was 3.7504 / 06 to the dollar.
One-month interbank deposits stood at 5-1/2, 3/8 percent, three-month deposits at 5-5/8, 1/2 percent and six-month deposits at 5-3/4, 5/8 percent.
One-year funds stood at six, 5-7/8 percent.
Israel approves Arafat's flight to the West Bank.
JERUSALEM 1996-08-22
Israel on Thursday gave permission to Palestinian President Yasser Arafat to fly from its territory to the West Bank, ending a brief Israeli-PLO crisis, an Arafat adviser said.
"The problem is over.
The president's plane has been cleared to pass through Israeli airspace, but the president is not expected to travel to the West Bank before Monday, Nabil Abu Rdainah told Reuters.

Arafat had been scheduled to meet former Israeli Prime Minister Shimon Peres in Ramallah, West Bank, on Thursday, but the venue was moved to Gaza after Israel refused to grant the Palestinian leader permission to fly his helicopters.
Palestinian officials have accused right-wing Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of trying to block the Ramallah meeting by keeping Arafat on the ground.
Arafat subsequently cancelled a meeting between Israeli and PLO officials at the Allenby Bridge between Jordan and the West Bank on civilian issues.
Abu Rdainah said that Arafat decided not to fly to the West Bank on Thursday after Israel lifted the ban because he had a busy schedule in Gaza and would not be free until Monday.
Arafat meets Peres in Gaza after the no-fly zone.
JERUSALEM 1996-08-22

Yasser Arafat will meet Shimon Peres in Gaza on Thursday after Palestinians say the right-wing Israeli government banned the Palestinian leader from flying to the West Bank to hold talks with the former prime minister.

Japanese Finance Minister Wataru Kubo told a news conference on Wednesday that he believes the Bank of Japan's (BOJ) interest rate policy, which is aimed at ensuring economic growth, has not changed after the publication of the central bank's "tankan" survey.
